docs.lead_paragraph: If you are like most people I know, chances are you are thoroughly confused about cholesterol and what you have to do to reduce your chances of suffering a heart attack or stroke. For those who must take cholesterol-lowering drugs, the confusion has been compounded by the recall this month of a leading medication, Baycol, after 31 deaths from kidney failure caused by excessive muscle breakdown. Only a minority of Americans adhere to the rather straightforward advice on cardiovascular disease prevention offered eight years ago by the National Cholesterol Education Program of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. And new guidelines, issued by the institute last spring, may have caused further confusion by creating many more categories of people who should be doing something about the kinds and amounts of fatty substances in their blood.

headline.main: Plotting an Attack On Your Cholesterol

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers guidance to people who are confused about how to go about reducing amount of cholesterol in their blood; chart of risk factors in assessing heart health (M)
docs.snippet: If you are like most people I know, chances are you are thoroughly confused about cholesterol and what you have to do to reduce your chances of suffering a heart attack or stroke. For those who must take cholesterol-lowering drugs, the confusion has...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was too happy a day for such a sight. Early in the morning three weeks ago, my wife gave birth to our son. Hours later, I returned home to get my daughter. We collected a pile of presents for the baby and a separate but equal pile for the brand new big sister. Then we drove back to the hospital where, outside the entrance, we saw them.

headline.main: A Day of Joy, Clouded by Smoke

docs.abstract: Marek Fuchs County Lines column on feeling joyful about seeing his newborn son but troubled by seeing ailing patients outside hospital smoking cigarettes; remembers childhood filled with smoke from his mother's two-pack-a-day habit; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The dispute between the Brazilian government and Roche, the Swiss drug maker, intensified yesterday as the company asked to meet with the country's health minister, who repeated his threat to authorize generic copies of Roche's AIDS medicine Viracept. Roche executives said yesterday that they were surprised to learn that Jose Serra, the Brazilian health minister, planned to break the patent that prevents production of generic versions of Viracept. Roche said the price of Viracept in Brazil had already been reduced to about 50 percent of its cost in the United States, where a patient's annual dosage can cost thousands of dollars.

headline.main: Roche Asks for Meeting With Brazil Health Minister

docs.abstract: Dispute between Brazilian government and Swiss drug maker Roche intensifies as company asks to meet with country's health minister, Jose Serra, who repeats his threat to authorize generic copies of Roche's AIDS medicine Viracept (M)

byline.original: By MELODY PETERSEN with JENNIFER L. RICH

docs.lead_paragraph: The French and German governments have come together in a request to the United Nations to approve a measure seeking a worldwide ban on human cloning for reproductive purposes. In a joint statement, the two nations have called on Secretary General Kofi Annan to present their proposal to the General Assembly, which meets in September. They urge the creation of a working group to draft a convention that would ban reproductive cloning as an offense ''to human dignity.''

headline.main: France and Germany Jointly Seek a Ban on Cloning Humans

docs.abstract: French and German governments ask UN to approve call for worldwide ban on human cloning for reproductive purposes; will also seek US support; Foreign Ministers Joschka Fischer and Hubert Vedrine met in June to plan renewed cooperation on range of issues; photo (M)
